results.title: Everyone's full bottle now
results.creator_credit: Simon Target and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Academy”.
The Academy looks at life as a new cadet at ADFA - the Australian Defence Force Academy in Canberra. “Full bottle now” introduces Ilana Napier, a new cadet who leaves her family and home to spend three years training at ADFA and the struggles and challenges she experiences. This is also an important time at ADFA because they are undertaking a new experiment with training whereby new cadets will be trained by staff instead of by third year cadets. Kizzy Hyde shares her experiences and takes the viewer on a tour of the barracks as a third year cadet.

results.title: The Deep frontier
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The 21st Century”.
An exploration of the ocean floor in a diving bell submarine that takes divers to an underwater residence for aquanauts. Among other devices shown are a four-story laboratory, a submarine with wheels and a remote controlled recovery robot. Interviews by Walter Cronkite with specialists in this area of research, including Jacques Cousteau, are featured also.

group_siblings.title: The Sleepwatchers
group_siblings.creator_credit: James Jackson, Isaac Kleinerman and Columbia Broadcasting System

results.title: The Sleepwatchers
results.creator_credit: James Jackson, Isaac Kleinerman and Columbia Broadcasting System
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The 21st Century”.
Presents a report on current research being done on various aspects of sleep. How much sleep human beings need, what happens to someone deprived of sleep, what sleep is like for the mentally ill, what causes sleepwalking and how to cure it and how much time each night is spent dreaming are among some of the questions dealt with in this film. Reporter: Walter Cronkite.

results.title: Forster and Lawrence
results.creator_credit: Alasdair Clayre and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The 19th Century Novel”.
Richard Hoggart discusses with Graham Martin the contrast between the prose style of D.H. Lawrence and E.M. Forster, with particular reference to the “Fox” and “Where Angels Fear to Tread”.

results.title: The Novel and television
results.creator_credit: Alasdair Clayre, Open University and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The 19th Century Novel”.
A discussion on some of the differences between the novel in its television dramatised form and the original prose. The film uses the problems involved in dramatisation as a way of discussing the novels concerned. The novels dealt with are Cousin Bette and Great Expectations.

results.title: Virginia Woolf's criticism of the novel 'Life escapes'
results.creator_credit: Richard Callanan, Open University and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The 19th Century Novel”.
Following a dramatised scene from Virginia Woolf’s novel “Life Escapes”, Professor Arnold Kettle argues that Virginia Woolf was not just telling a story but recreating an era of reality and this leads her to break with the traditional form of the novel in a way which emphasises the moment-to-moment impressions of life.

results.title: Tolstoy after Anna Karenina
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The 19th Century Novel”.
After publishing Anna Karenina Tolstoy suffered a crisis in his personal and public life. The question which in Anna Karenina haunts Levin “Why am I?” became more and more urgent to Tolstoy and his answers became more extreme. He was a man who craved solitude, but his admirers almost made this impossible for him. Tolstoy died on 7 November 1910. Documentary also features Russian writers Godky and Chekov. Uses archival footage and stills.

results.title: Charles Dicken's expectations: a dream of childhood
results.creator_credit: Paul Kafno, Open University and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The 19th century novel”.
Graham Martin explores Pip’s character in terms of the surrender of childish dreams, and draws parallels with Dickens’ own life. The film is set on locations in Kent, at Dickens’ home at Gade Hill, and in London. Presented by Graham Martin, reader in literature. Voice of Charles Dickens read by Gabriel Woolf.
